@def-Density.blockBody:
We call define *density of a subset $A\subseteq\Group$ with respect to a
Følner sequence, $\Folner$,* as
$$\Density(A)=\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\frac{|\Folner[N]\cap A|}{|\Folner[N]|},$$
if it exists.

@def-Folner.blockBody:
We call a sequence a *Følner sequence* if it is both a left and right
Følner sequence.

@def-group.blockBody:
A group is a non-empty set $\Group$ together with a binary operation on
$\Group$, denoted "$\GroupOperation{}{}$", that combines any two
elements $\GroupElement$ and $\GroupElement'$ of $\Group$ to form an
element of $\Group$, denoted
$\GroupOperation{\GroupElement}{\GroupElement'}$, such that the
following three requirements, known as **group axioms**, are satisfied:

-   {{\< term ref="def-associativity"
    templateMap="\[\\Group,\\GroupOperation,\\Identity,g,h,j\]" \>}}
-   {{\< term ref="def-identity"
    templateMap="\[\\Group,\\GroupOperation,\\Identity,g,h,j\]" \>}}
-   {{\< term ref="def-uniqueInverse"
    templateMap="\[\\Group,\\GroupOperation,\\Identity,g,h,j\]" \>}}

@def-identity.blockBody:
There exists an element $\Identity$ in $\Set$ such that, for every
${#1}$ in $\Set$, one has $\Operation{\Identity}{#1}={#1}$ and
$\Operation{#1}{\Identity}={#1}$. Such an element is unique and is
called the **identity element**.

@def-leftFolner.blockBody:
Similarly, we define a *left-Følner sequence* in a group, $\Group$, as a
sequence $\Folner =(\Folner[N])_{N\in\mathbb{N}}$ of finite subsets of
$\Gamma$ satisfying
$$\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\frac{|(\Inverse{\GroupElement}\cdot\Folner[N])\cap\Folner[N]|}{|\Folner[N]|}=1 $$for
all $\GroupElement\in\Group$.

@def-rightFolner.blockBody:
We define a *right-Følner sequence* in a group, $\Group$, as a sequence
$\Folner =(\Folner[N])_{N\in\mathbb{N}}$ of finite subsets of $\Gamma$
satisfying
$$\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\frac{|\GroupOperation{(\GroupOperation{\Folner[N]}{\Inverse{\GroupElement}})}{\Folner[N]}|}{|\Folner[N]|}=1$$for
all $\GroupElement\in\Group$.

@def-uniqueInverse.blockBody:
For each ${#1}$ in $\Set$, there exists an element ${#2}$ in $\Set$ such
that $\Operation{#1}{#2}=\Identity$ and $\Operation{#2}{#1}=\Identity$,
where $\Identity$ is the identity element.

For each ${#1}$, the element ${#2}$ is unique and is called the
**inverse** of ${#2}$ and is denoted $\Inverse{#1}$.
